name: Criminal Behavior Analysis
description: Techniques for analyzing criminal behavior and psychological motivations.

cards.title: Deception Patterns in Criminal Behavior
cards.description: Identifying lies, inconsistencies, and deceptive behaviors in suspects.
bulletpoints: Analyze microexpressions (involuntary facial movements) to detect deception
Use Statement Analysis to identify linguistic inconsistencies in suspect testimonies
Apply cognitive load techniques (e.g., unexpected questions) to expose lies
cards.summaryText: Pair microexpression reads with statement scrutiny and surprise probes to fracture criminal deceptions.

cards.title: Traits of Serial Offenders & Recidivists
cards.description: Examining patterns of repeat offenders and serial criminals.
bulletpoints: Profile the psychological motivators behind serial offenses (compulsion, control, power)
Differentiate between organized (methodical, planned) and disorganized (impulsive, erratic) criminal behavior
Use behavioral pattern recognition to predict escalation in criminal activity
cards.summaryText: Map why repeat offenders act, classify organized versus chaotic signatures, and watch for escalation cues.

cards.title: Understanding Criminal Motivations
cards.description: Examining why criminals commit crimes and their psychological drivers.
bulletpoints: Study the Routine Activity Theory (RAT)—how opportunity and motivation intersect
Understand intrinsic vs. extrinsic motivators (psychological vs. situational drivers)
Use the Crime Classification Manual (CCM) to categorize offender typologies
cards.summaryText: Blend RAT, motive sources, and CCM typologies to see what fuels a crime and where it fits.

cards.title: Psychopathy vs. Sociopathy in Criminal Behavior
cards.description: Distinguishing psychopathy and sociopathy in criminal offenders.
bulletpoints: Use the Hare Psychopathy Checklist-Revised (PCL-R) to assess psychopathic traits
Differentiate between primary psychopathy (cold, calculating) and secondary sociopathy (impulsive, reactive)
Analyze case studies of infamous psychopaths and sociopaths in criminal history
cards.summaryText: Score offenders with the PCL-R, separate calculated psychopaths from reactive sociopaths, and anchor insights in casework.

cards.title: Victimology & Target Selection
cards.description: Analyzing how criminals select their victims and the patterns of victimization.
bulletpoints: Study the Victim-Offender Overlap (VOO)—how some victims and offenders share backgrounds
Understand target selection strategies (opportunistic vs. premeditated victimization)
Use crime mapping to identify high-risk areas and serial offender hunting grounds
cards.summaryText: Track VOO patterns, decode how targets are chosen, and map hotspots to anticipate the next strike.

cards.title: Threat Assessment & Risk Evaluation
cards.description: Predicting dangerous behavior through structured risk assessment tools.
bulletpoints: Use Structured Professional Judgment (SPJ) models to assess risk (e.g., HCR-20 for violence risk assessment)
Evaluate Behavioral Threat Assessment (BTA) indicators for workplace and public safety threats
Analyze pre-attack behaviors in individuals likely to commit violent acts
cards.summaryText: Run SPJ tools, flag BTA indicators, and compare pre-attack scripts to forecast dangerous moves.

cards.title: Understanding Stalking & Fixation Behaviors
cards.description: Profiling individuals who engage in stalking and persistent harassment.
bulletpoints: Differentiate between intimacy-seeking, resentful, and predatory stalkers
Use the Stalking Risk Profile (SRP) tool to evaluate threat levels
Analyze patterns of obsessive behaviors leading to escalation
cards.summaryText: Classify stalker style, score risk with SRP, and trace obsession arcs to spot escalation windows.

cards.title: Digital Criminal Behavior & Cyber Offenders
cards.description: Profiling cybercriminals, online fraudsters, and dark web offenders.
bulletpoints: Categorize cybercriminal typologies (e.g., hacktivists, cyberstalkers, financial fraudsters)
Analyze Dark Web behaviors to track cybercriminal activity
Use digital footprint tracking to uncover anonymous online offenders
cards.summaryText: Sort cyber offenders, mine dark web patterns, and stitch digital breadcrumbs back to real operators.

cards.title: Analyzing Organized Crime Networks
bulletpoints: Use Social Network Analysis (SNA) to map criminal syndicates
Identify hierarchical vs. decentralized gang structures
Study money laundering methods used by transnational crime syndicates
cards.summaryText: Model syndicates with SNA, contrast chain-of-command styles, and trace laundering pipelines to disrupt networks.

cards.title: Narcissism & Power in Criminal Behavior
cards.description: Examining the role of narcissistic traits in criminal activity.
bulletpoints: Differentiate between grandiose vs. vulnerable narcissists in crime
Study power-seeking behaviors in white-collar criminals and cult leaders
Use forensic psychology to assess manipulation tactics in offenders
cards.summaryText: Pinpoint narcissist subtype, map power grabs, and document manipulative playbooks via forensic interviews.

cards.title: Understanding False Confessions
cards.description: Analyzing why individuals confess to crimes they didn’t commit.
bulletpoints: Study Reid Interrogation Technique and its role in false confessions
Recognize coercion tactics used in police interrogations
Analyze wrongful conviction cases where psychological pressure led to false admissions
cards.summaryText: Dissect coercive interrogation tactics, flag risky practices, and learn from wrongful conviction case studies.

cards.title: Psychological Pathways to Violent Extremism
cards.description: Profiling individuals who become radicalized into violent extremist groups.
bulletpoints: Understand social identity theory and its role in radicalization
Analyze online propaganda and recruitment methods used by extremist groups
Use Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) methodologies to identify early warning signs
cards.summaryText: Blend social identity theory, propaganda analysis, and CVE frameworks to intercept violent radicalization paths.
